elements.content: Constructing a hybrid connection mode between cluster-based building blocks is of particular importance in the pursuit of fascinating framework structures. Reported here are two new metal chalcogenide imidazolate frameworks (SCIF-11 and SCIF-12) with a hybrid intercluster bridging mode and a unique interrupted topological structure. SCIF-11 has a typical dia topology with a T3-InS supertetrahedral cluster as the node and an imidazolate (IM) ligand as the linker, but it for the first time combines two kinds of intercluster connecting modes: T3–S–T3 and T3–IM–T3. Interestingly, SCIF-12 composed of T4-CdInS supertetrahedral clusters and IM ligands possesses a unique 3,4-connected interrupted framework with ins topology, with this being the first case in the family of cluster-based metal chalcogenide frameworks. This work provides a new strategy on enriching the intercluster bridging modes and topological types of metal chalcogenide frameworks.
elements.clean_text: Constructing a hybrid connection mode between cluster-based building blocks is of particular importance in the pursuit of fascinating framework structures. Reported here are two new metal chalcogenide imidazolate frameworks (SCIF-11 and SCIF-12) with a hybrid intercluster bridging mode and a unique interrupted topological structure. SCIF-11 has a typical dia topology with a T3-InS supertetrahedral cluster as the node and an imidazolate (IM) ligand as the linker, but it for the first time combines two kinds of intercluster connecting modes: T3-S-T3 and T3-IM-T3. Interestingly, SCIF-12 composed of T4-CdInS supertetrahedral clusters and IM ligands possesses a unique 3,4-connected interrupted framework with ins topology, with this being the first case in the family of cluster-based metal chalcogenide frameworks. This work provides a new strategy on enriching the intercluster bridging modes and topological types of metal chalcogenide frameworks.

elements.content: Two new metal chalcogenide imidazolate frameworks are as follows: the hybrid intercluster bridging modes (T3−S−T3 and T3−IM−T3) were observed for the first time in SCIF-11, and a unique interrupted topological structure was found in SCIF-12.
elements.clean_text: Two new metal chalcogenide imidazolate frameworks are as follows: the hybrid intercluster bridging modes (T3-S-T3 and T3-IM-T3) were observed for the first time in SCIF-11, and a unique interrupted topological structure was found in SCIF-12.

elements.content: Crystalline open-framework metal chalcogenide materials have attracted interest during the past 2 decades because of integration of the porosity with semiconducting properties, which makes them exhibit prominent abilities in ion exchange, gas absorption, photoelectric response, and photocatalysis. As one of the main existing forms of crystalline metal chalcogenide open frameworks, Tn-based chalcogenide frameworks have experienced rapid development in the aspect of framework topologies. Interestingly, the basic secondary building units (SBUs) in Tn-based frameworks can be recognized as tetrahedrally shaped fragments of the cubic zinc blende type (n represents the number of metal layers along the supertetrahedral edge for a typical isolated Tn cluster). T6-ZnInS with a formula of [Zn25In31S84]25– is the largest Tn cluster so far. To be noticed, the formation of a Tn-based open framework is based on the fact that Tn clusters are usually spontaneously assembled into diverse structures by sharing the corner sulfur atom via various coordination modes, such as μ2-S2– (e.g., UCR-7), μ3-S2– (e.g., UCR-8, OCF-89, and CIS-27), and μ4-S2– (e.g., CIS-11). However, there is increasing difficulty in continuously preparing more fascinating open-framework structures if only above traditional connecting modes, i.e., sharing the corner anionic sulfur (or selenium) sites, were adopted. Hence, novel intercluster connecting modes are desirable to expand the metal chalcogenide open frameworks.
elements.clean_text: Crystalline open-framework metal chalcogenide materials have attracted interest during the past 2 decades because of integration of the porosity with semiconducting properties, which makes them exhibit prominent abilities in ion exchange, gas absorption, photoelectric response, and photocatalysis. As one of the main existing forms of crystalline metal chalcogenide open frameworks, Tn-based chalcogenide frameworks have experienced rapid development in the aspect of framework topologies. Interestingly, the basic secondary building units (SBUs) in Tn-based frameworks can be recognized as tetrahedrally shaped fragments of the cubic zinc blende type (n represents the number of metal layers along the supertetrahedral edge for a typical isolated Tn cluster). T6-ZnInS with a formula of [Zn25In31S84]25- is the largest Tn cluster so far. To be noticed, the formation of a Tn-based open framework is based on the fact that Tn clusters are usually spontaneously assembled into diverse structures by sharing the corner sulfur atom via various coordination modes, such as μ2-S2- (e.g., UCR-7), μ3-S2- (e.g., UCR-8, OCF-89, and CIS-27), and μ4-S2- (e.g., CIS-11). However, there is increasing difficulty in continuously preparing more fascinating open-framework structures if only above traditional connecting modes, i.e., sharing the corner anionic sulfur (or selenium) sites, were adopted. Hence, novel intercluster connecting modes are desirable to expand the metal chalcogenide open frameworks.

elements.content: The incorporation of organic components into Tn-based inorganic chalcogenide frameworks has been found to provide big potentials in constructing hybrid structures with new topological networks and exploring synergistic effects between organic moieties and semiconducting clusters. Bipyridine (Bpy) and its derivatives were first applied as linkers to prepare a series of T3-GaS-based hybrid structures through T3–Bpy–T3 intercluster bridging modes. Such cases provided an effective strategy to extend hybrid chalcogenide frameworks and further revealed that the incorporation of nitrogen-containing heterocycle ligands can enrich the architectures of Tn-based chalcogenide frameworks. Afterward, inspired by the development of well-known zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), imidazolate and its derivatives were also successfully incorporated into Tn-based open frameworks by Feng’s group (denoted as supertetrahedral cluster imidazolate frameworks, SCIFs). Nevertheless, only multiple-fold interpenetrated dia topological structures (double-interpenetrated dia with the T3 cluster and triple-interpenetrated dia with the T4 cluster as building units) were obtained.
elements.clean_text: The incorporation of organic components into Tn-based inorganic chalcogenide frameworks has been found to provide big potentials in constructing hybrid structures with new topological networks and exploring synergistic effects between organic moieties and semiconducting clusters. Bipyridine (Bpy) and its derivatives were first applied as linkers to prepare a series of T3-GaS-based hybrid structures through T3-Bpy-T3 intercluster bridging modes. Such cases provided an effective strategy to extend hybrid chalcogenide frameworks and further revealed that the incorporation of nitrogen-containing heterocycle ligands can enrich the architectures of Tn-based chalcogenide frameworks. Afterward, inspired by the development of well-known zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), imidazolate and its derivatives were also successfully incorporated into Tn-based open frameworks by Feng's group (denoted as supertetrahedral cluster imidazolate frameworks, SCIFs). Nevertheless, only multiple-fold interpenetrated dia topological structures (double-interpenetrated dia with the T3 cluster and triple-interpenetrated dia with the T4 cluster as building units) were obtained.

elements.content: Apart from the hybrid structure, great attention was focused on the construction of the interrupted frameworks. The creation of interrupted sites in the framework has proven to be a promising strategy to build extralarge pores and channels. Even so, interrupted sites are very rare in natural zeolite frameworks, and only 11 out of 224 frameworks have the interrupted structure. So far, the interrupted frameworks were also observed in metal–organic frameworks, such as ZIF-100 containing colossal cages with an interrupted chlorine atom, and BIF-10 with three-coordinated BH­(MIm)3 – as interrupted building blocks. In addition, an interrupted chalcogenide-based zeolite analogue framework was reported with tunable electro/photoelectron chemical properties, in which T2 clusters were partially interrupted by oxygen atoms from H2O at one corner. Even more recently, a 36-MR (membered ring) metal chalcogenide with a very low framework density was obtained because of the terminal sulfur atoms, and a 3D metal selenide interrupted framework (CSZ-9) was obtained by the assembly of 3-connected T2-InSe SBUs and 4-connected P1-InSe SBUs. Theoretically speaking, the coexistence of 2-, 3-, and 4-connected Tn clusters in one network caused by the interruption sites can offer enormous opportunities to construct a more complicated and amazing structure.
elements.clean_text: Apart from the hybrid structure, great attention was focused on the construction of the interrupted frameworks. The creation of interrupted sites in the framework has proven to be a promising strategy to build extralarge pores and channels. Even so, interrupted sites are very rare in natural zeolite frameworks, and only 11 out of 224 frameworks have the interrupted structure. So far, the interrupted frameworks were also observed in metal-organic frameworks, such as ZIF-100 containing colossal cages with an interrupted chlorine atom, and BIF-10 with three-coordinated BH(MIm)3 - as interrupted building blocks. In addition, an interrupted chalcogenide-based zeolite analogue framework was reported with tunable electro/photoelectron chemical properties, in which T2 clusters were partially interrupted by oxygen atoms from H2O at one corner. Even more recently, a 36-MR (membered ring) metal chalcogenide with a very low framework density was obtained because of the terminal sulfur atoms, and a 3D metal selenide interrupted framework (CSZ-9) was obtained by the assembly of 3-connected T2-InSe SBUs and 4-connected P1-InSe SBUs. Theoretically speaking, the coexistence of 2-, 3-, and 4-connected Tn clusters in one network caused by the interruption sites can offer enormous opportunities to construct a more complicated and amazing structure.

elements.content: Herein, two new metal chalcogenide imidazolate frameworks, [(In10S17)­(IM)]·(H+-DBU)5 (SCIF-11) and [(Cd4In16S31.5)­(IM)1.75]·(H+-DBU)8.75 (SCIF-12), where IM = imidazolate and DBU = 1, 8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]­undec-7-ene, were successfully prepared through a solvothermal reaction. The combination of intercluster connecting modes (T3–S–T3 and T3–IM–T3) in SCIF-11 is for the first time observed in the family of metal chalcogenide imidazolate frameworks. In addition, SCIF-12 displays an interrupted network with unique ins topology, which results from the coexistence of 3- and 4-connected T4-CdInS clusters because of the interruption at partial corners.
elements.clean_text: Herein, two new metal chalcogenide imidazolate frameworks, [(In10S17)(IM)]⋅(H+-DBU)5 (SCIF-11) and [(Cd4In16S31.5)(IM)1.75]⋅(H+-DBU)8.75 (SCIF-12), where IM = imidazolate and DBU = 1, 8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene, were successfully prepared through a solvothermal reaction. The combination of intercluster connecting modes (T3-S-T3 and T3-IM-T3) in SCIF-11 is for the first time observed in the family of metal chalcogenide imidazolate frameworks. In addition, SCIF-12 displays an interrupted network with unique ins topology, which results from the coexistence of 3- and 4-connected T4-CdInS clusters because of the interruption at partial corners.

elements.content: SCIF-11 and SCIF-12 were synthesized via a solvothermal reaction, and their crystal structures were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Synthetically speaking, SCIF-11 can only be obtained by using indium powder and sulfur powder as precursors, and only the combination of soluble salts of In­(NO3)3 and Cd­(NO3)2 with thiourea is feasible for the preparation of SCIF-12, in which the ratio of Cd2+ and imidazolates is a critical factor; otherwise, only amorphous jellies were obtained. In addition, the solvent of an amidine-related DBU is highly necessary in the coassembly process of clusters and organic ligands. Numerous experiments indicated that only UCR-7 with interconnected T3 clusters or a compound with discrete T3 clusters in the crystal lattice were obtained without the participation of DBUs. A similar case was also found in the preparation of isolated hybrid supertetrahedral chalcogenide clusters (ISC-n ), in which amidine-related DBN (1,5-diazabicyclo[4.3.0]­non-5-ene) acts as terminal agent and its protonated form is needed to stabilize the negatively charged cluster. It was speculated that DBU molecules can serve as not only structure-directing agents but also a superbase to accelerate the deprotonation of imidazole and facilitate the assembly of organic ligands and inorganic clusters.
elements.clean_text: SCIF-11 and SCIF-12 were synthesized via a solvothermal reaction, and their crystal structures were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Synthetically speaking, SCIF-11 can only be obtained by using indium powder and  sulfur powder as precursors, and only the combination of soluble salts of In(NO3)3 and Cd(NO3)2 with thiourea is feasible for the preparation of SCIF-12, in which the ratio of Cd2+ and imidazolates is a critical factor; otherwise, only amorphous jellies were obtained. In addition, the solvent of an amidine-related DBU is highly necessary in the coassembly process of clusters and organic ligands. Numerous experiments indicated that only UCR-7 with interconnected T3 clusters or a compound with discrete T3 clusters in the crystal lattice were obtained without the participation of DBUs. A similar case was also found in the preparation of isolated hybrid supertetrahedral chalcogenide clusters (ISC-n ), in which amidine-related DBN (1,5-diazabicyclo[4.3.0]non-5-ene) acts as terminal agent and its protonated form is needed to stabilize the negatively charged cluster. It was speculated that DBU molecules can serve as not only structure-directing agents but also a superbase to accelerate the deprotonation of imidazole and facilitate the assembly of organic ligands and inorganic clusters.

elements.content: The crystal structural analysis revealed that SCIF-11 crystallized in an orthorhombic system with a space group of Pbca. It has a 3D structure with hybrid intercluster bridging modes between T3-InS building units. Each T3 cluster connects to four surrounding T3 clusters by sharing two IMs and two μ2-S2– atoms at tetrahedral corners, respectively. In fact, with the number of IM linkers increasing, the negative charge density of the framework slightly decreases. Structurally speaking, SCIF-11 can be rationally regarded as an intermediate state between the entirely inorganic T3-interconnected UCR-7 ([In10S18]6–) and hybrid SCIF-1 ([(In10S16)­(IM)2]4–) with the entire T3–IM connection mode (a–c). SCIF-11 shows a distorted double-interpenetrated dia topological structure because of the coexistence of two kinds of connecting modes (a,b and S11 and S12).
elements.clean_text: The crystal structural analysis revealed that SCIF-11 crystallized in an orthorhombic system with a space group of Pbca. It has a 3D structure with hybrid intercluster bridging modes between T3-InS building units. Each T3 cluster connects to four surrounding T3 clusters by sharing two IMs and two μ2-S2- atoms at tetrahedral corners, respectively. In fact, with the number of IM linkers increasing, the negative charge density of the framework slightly decreases. Structurally speaking, SCIF-11 can be rationally regarded as an intermediate state between the entirely inorganic T3-interconnected UCR-7 ([In10S18]6-) and hybrid SCIF-1 ([(In10S16)(IM)2]4-) with the entire T3-IM connection mode (a-c). SCIF-11 shows a distorted double-interpenetrated dia topological structure because of the coexistence of two kinds of connecting modes (a,b and S11 and S12).

elements.content: Various intercluster connecting modes between T3-InS clusters: (a) T3–S–T3 connection mode in UCR-7; (b) hybrid T3–S–T3 and T3–IM–T3 connection modes in SCIF-11; (c) T3–IM–T3 connection mode in SCIF-1; (d) interrupted T4 cluster with three corners bonding to the T4 cluster via the T4–IM–T4 connection mode and one terminated corner by −SH in SCIF-12; (e) 4-connected T4 cluster with four corners bonding to T4 via the T4–IM–T4 connection mode in SCIF-12.
elements.clean_text: 1  Various intercluster connecting modes between T3-InS clusters: (a) T3-S-T3 connection mode in UCR-7; (b) hybrid T3-S-T3 and T3-IM-T3 connection modes in SCIF-11; (c) T3-IM-T3 connection mode in SCIF-1; (d) interrupted T4 cluster with three corners bonding to the T4 cluster via the T4-IM-T4 connection mode and one terminated corner by -SH in SCIF-12; (e) 4-connected T4 cluster with four corners bonding to T4 via the T4-IM-T4 connection mode in SCIF-12.

elements.content: 3D structure of SCIF-11: (a) 6-MR delimited by T3 clusters viewed along the a axis; (b) single dia topology viewed along the a axis.
elements.clean_text: 2  3D structure of SCIF-11: (a) 6-MR delimited by T3 clusters viewed along the a axis; (b) single dia topology viewed along the a axis.

elements.content: SCIF-12 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pnnn. It has a 3D structure composed of 3- and 4-connected T4-CdInS clusters. Different from the 4-connected T4 cluster bonding to four adjacent ones through IM linkers, the 3-connected T4 cluster has a terminal group of −SH at one corner (d,e). The 3- and 4-connected T4 clusters are distributed at regular intervals in the ratio of 1:1. Benefiting from the interrupted T4 cluster, an unprecedented 3,4-connected structure was obtained in SCIF-12 (a), which can also be regarded as a 3D framework evolving from 2D wavylike layers connected to each other via 4-connected T4 clusters (b,c). In addition, SCIF-12 can be classified into chalcogenide-based interrupted frameworks with a unique 3,4-connected ins topological structure. Such an interrupted framework has a point symbol of (63)­(65.8) (d). Assuming that all T4 clusters adopt a 4-connected mode, a topology with five 6-MR other than four 6-MR dia topology would be formed (e). In addition, the interrupted framework has a large potential void space of 68.1% (calculated by PLATON software), which results from the extralarge channels delimited by Z-shaped 10-MR (Figures S13 and S14). A previous study on traditional metal chalcogenide-based open frameworks demonstrated that only ladder-like or layered structures were available using 3-connected Tn clusters as SBUs (e.g., hcb); 4-connected dia nets were the most common cases if 4-connected Tn clusters are used as SBUs, and few examples adopt sod and crb topology. In fact, there are nine frameworks with only dia topology structures reported before in the SCIF series. Therefore, introducing the interrupted defects at terminal sites of Tn clusters here proves to be a good strategy for breaking up the limitation in structural topology.
elements.clean_text: SCIF-12 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pnnn. It has a 3D structure composed of 3- and 4-connected T4-CdInS clusters. Different from the 4-connected T4 cluster bonding to four adjacent ones through IM linkers, the 3-connected T4 cluster has a terminal group of -SH at one corner (d,e). The 3- and 4-connected T4 clusters are distributed at regular intervals in the ratio of 1:1. Benefiting from the interrupted T4 cluster, an unprecedented 3,4-connected structure was obtained in SCIF-12 (a), which can also be regarded as a 3D framework evolving from 2D wavylike layers connected to each other via 4-connected T4 clusters (b,c). In addition, SCIF-12 can be classified into chalcogenide-based interrupted frameworks with a unique 3,4-connected ins topological structure. Such an interrupted framework has a point symbol of (63)(65.8) (d). Assuming that all T4 clusters adopt a 4-connected mode, a topology with five 6-MR other than four 6-MR dia topology would be formed (e). In addition, the interrupted framework has a large potential void space of 68.1% (calculated by PLATON software), which results from the extralarge channels delimited by Z-shaped 10-MR (Figures S13 and S14). A previous study on traditional metal chalcogenide-based open frameworks demonstrated that only ladder-like or layered structures were available using 3-connected Tn clusters as SBUs (e.g., hcb); 4-connected dia nets were the most common cases if 4-connected Tn clusters are used as SBUs, and few examples adopt sod and crb topology. In fact, there are nine frameworks with only dia topology structures reported before in the SCIF series. Therefore, introducing the interrupted defects at terminal sites of Tn clusters here proves to be a good strategy for breaking up the limitation in structural topology.

elements.content: 3D structure of SCIF-12: (a) schematic diagram of the assembly process for the formation of Z-shaped 10-MR from interrupted sites and open frameworks; (b) ins topological structure; (c) a single 6,3-layered net from part b; (d) simplest ins topological unit; (e) conjectural topological unit when 3-connected T4 clusters are also treated as 4-connected nodes.
elements.clean_text: 3  3D structure of SCIF-12: (a) schematic diagram of the assembly process for the formation of Z-shaped 10-MR from interrupted sites and open frameworks; (b) ins topological structure; (c) a single 6,3-layered net from part b; (d) simplest ins topological unit; (e) conjectural topological unit when 3-connected T4 clusters are also treated as 4-connected nodes.

elements.content: Solid-state UV–vis diffuse-reflectance spectra and solid-state photoluminescence (PL) and PL excitation (PLE) spectra of SCIF-11 were investigated. Hybrid SCIF-1 and SCIF-11 show similar band gaps of ∼3.22 and ∼3.21 eV, respectively. However, UCR-7 with an entirely inorganic framework has a larger band gap of ∼3.45 eV than the above hybrid ones (a). There is no obvious PL emission for UCR-7 and neutral ligand H-IM at room temperature. However, the significant and obvious PL emission of SCIF-1 and SCIF-11 are clearly observed at emissions of 497 and 463 nm under excitations of 418 and 394 nm, respectively (b). In addition, the quantum yield of SCIF-1 and SCIF-11 were measured to be 18.26% and 20.93%, respectively (Figures S15 and S16). The single-crystal UV–vis absorption spectrum of SCIF-12 shows a band gap of ∼3.34 eV (c), and its single-crystal PL emission is also observed at 446 nm under an excitation of 365 nm (d). Although UCR-7 shows no PL emission at room temperature, the PL behaviors of SCIF-1, SCIF-11, and SCIF-12 are all obviously observed. According to the previous research and our current cases, the PL emissions of SCIF-1, SCIF-11, and SCIF-12 are probably attributed to the π*−π transition of the IM ligand. The difference in the luminescent behavior of SCIF-1, SCIF-11, and SCIF-12 is probably attributed to the difference in the spatial configuration of the IM ligand caused by the hybrid intercluster bridging mode, which further results in the different energy gap of the π–π* transition.
elements.clean_text: Solid-state UV-vis diffuse-reflectance spectra and solid-state photoluminescence (PL) and PL excitation (PLE) spectra of SCIF-11 were investigated. Hybrid SCIF-1 and SCIF-11 show similar band gaps of ~3.22 and ~3.21 eV, respectively. However, UCR-7 with an entirely inorganic framework has a larger band gap of ~3.45 eV than the above hybrid ones (a). There is no obvious PL emission for UCR-7 and neutral ligand H-IM at room temperature. However, the significant and obvious PL emission of SCIF-1 and SCIF-11 are clearly observed at emissions of 497 and 463 nm under excitations of 418 and 394 nm, respectively (b). In addition, the quantum yield of SCIF-1 and SCIF-11 were measured to be 18.26% and 20.93%, respectively (Figures S15 and S16). The single-crystal UV-vis absorption spectrum of SCIF-12 shows a band gap of ~3.34 eV (c), and its single-crystal PL emission is also observed at 446 nm under an excitation of 365 nm (d). Although UCR-7 shows no PL emission at room temperature, the PL behaviors of SCIF-1, SCIF-11, and SCIF-12 are all obviously observed. According to the previous research and our current cases, the PL emissions of SCIF-1, SCIF-11, and SCIF-12 are probably attributed to the π*-π transition of the IM ligand. The difference in the luminescent behavior of SCIF-1, SCIF-11, and SCIF-12 is probably attributed to the difference in the spatial configuration of the IM ligand caused by the hybrid intercluster bridging mode, which further results in the different energy gap of the π-π* transition.

elements.content: (a) Solid-state UV–vis absorption spectra of UCR-7, SCIF-1, and SCIF-11. (b) Solid-state PL and PLE spectra of SCIF-1 and SCIF-11. (c) Band gap of SCIF-12. (d) Single-crystal PL spectra of SCIF-12. The inset is the crystal picture of SCIF-12 recorded by an optical microscope.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Solid-state UV-vis absorption spectra of UCR-7, SCIF-1, and SCIF-11. (b) Solid-state PL and PLE spectra of SCIF-1 and SCIF-11. (c) Band gap of SCIF-12. (d) Single-crystal PL spectra of SCIF-12. The inset is the crystal picture of SCIF-12 recorded by an optical microscope.

elements.content: In conclusion, two new metal chalcogenide imidazolate frameworks have been successfully synthesized, including a double-interpenetrated dia framework (SCIF-11) with a hybrid intercluster bridging mode and a 3,4-connected interrupted framework (SCIF-12) with the first ins topology in supertetrahedral cluster-based chalcogenide frameworks. In addition, the UV–vis and PL properties revealed the difference between entirely inorganic chalcogenide frameworks and hybrid ones. The utilization of IMs and DBUs has proven to be beneficial for the competition and cooperation of different intercluster connecting modes, and more fascinating hybrid metal chalcogenide imidazolate frameworks with multiple intercluster connecting modes and topologies could be expected.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, two new metal chalcogenide imidazolate frameworks have been successfully synthesized, including a double-interpenetrated dia framework (SCIF-11) with a hybrid intercluster bridging mode and a 3,4-connected interrupted framework (SCIF-12) with the first ins topology in supertetrahedral cluster-based chalcogenide frameworks. In addition, the UV-vis and PL properties revealed the difference between entirely inorganic chalcogenide frameworks and hybrid ones. The utilization of IMs and DBUs has proven to be beneficial for the competition and cooperation of different intercluster connecting modes, and more fascinating hybrid metal chalcogenide imidazolate frameworks with multiple intercluster connecting modes and topologies could be expected.

(d) Single-crystal PL spectra of SCIF-12. The inset is the crystal picture of SCIF-12 recorded by an optical microscope.

metadata.title:

and Unique Interrupted Topological Structure
